original_prompt: Extract named entities and classify the tokens a under one of the following labels [I-LOC, B-ORG, O, B-PER, I-PER, I-MISC, B-MISC, I-ORG, B-LOC]. The format should be ["Token": "India", "NER_tag": "B-LOC", ..., ...]
optimized_prompt: Transform the following raw input into a structured news headline and summary. The headline should capture the main point of the news, and the summary should include relevant details, such as the who, what, when, and where. Format the output as 'Headline: [headline text]. Summary: [summary text]'. Input: {input_text}

evaluation_details: Headline: China Accuses Taiwan of Disrupting Talks Atmosphere Following VP's Visit to Ukraine. Summary: On August 22, 1996, China criticized Taiwan for undermining the potential for resuming political talks by having its Vice President Lien Chan visit Ukraine, an action that angered Beijing. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang stated that the atmosphere necessary for discussions has been disrupted by Taiwan authorities, despite prior statements from China's top negotiator advocating for talks to end hostilities.

Headline: China Calls for Political Talks with Taiwan. Summary: On August 22, 1996, in Beijing, China's Tang Shubei, executive vice chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, stated that the time is right for political discussions with Taiwan, urging the island to take practical steps towards initiating talks.

Headline: German Car Registrations Surge 14.2% in July 1996. Summary: In July 1996, German first-time motor vehicle registrations increased by 14.2% year-on-year, totaling 356,725 new vehicles, according to the Federal Office for Motor Vehicles. The growth includes a 13.6% rise in passenger car registrations to 304,850, while truck registrations saw a slight decline of 2.2%. Notably, motorcycle registrations surged by 32.7%. Volkswagen led with 77,719 registrations, followed by Opel and General Motors with 49,269, and Ford with 35,563. The increase is attributed in part to Germans purchasing cars abroad, despite weak domestic demand. Seat and Porsche experienced declines in registrations.

Headline: Greek Socialists Approve Snap Elections at PM's Request. Summary: On August 22, 1996, the executive bureau of the Greek socialist party granted Prime Minister Costas Simitis permission to call for snap elections, as announced by general secretary Costas Skandalidis. An official announcement from the Prime Minister is expected following a cabinet meeting later that day in Athens.

Headline: Bayerische Vereinsbank Issues C$100 Million Bond with Six-Year Maturity. Summary: On August 22, 1996, Bayerische Vereinsbank announced the issuance of a C$100 million bond, managed by Toronto Dominion, with a coupon rate of 6.625% and a maturity date set for September 24, 2002. The bond was priced at 100.92 and will have a pay date of September 24, 1996. The listing is in Luxembourg, with Moody's rating it AA1.

Headline: Venantius Announces $300 Million Floating Rate Note Set for January 1999. Summary: Venantius AB, acting as the Swedish National Mortgage Agency, has announced a $300 million floating-rate note (FRN) issue, with a discount spread of 12.5 basis points over a 3-month LIBOR. The issuance, managed by Lehman Brothers International, is set to mature on January 21, 1999, with the first coupon payment due on September 23, 1996. The notes are rated AA3 by Moody's and AA+ by S&P, with reoffer notes in denominations of 1, 10, and 100. The listing will take place in London, with sales allowed in the US, UK, Japan, and France.

Headline: Port Conditions in Syria Update: 24-Hour Wait Times at Lattakia and Tartous. Summary: As of August 10, Lloyds Shipping Intelligence Service reports that the waiting time for ships at the ports of Lattakia and Tartous in Syria is currently 24 hours.

Headline: Israel Downplays War Fears with Syria Amid Tensions and Calls for Peace Talks.  
Summary: On August 22, 1996, in Jerusalem, Itamar Rabinovich, Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria, indicated that the ongoing tensions between the two countries seemed exaggerated, describing them as a "storm in a teacup." Rabinovich suggested that Damascus is more interested in negotiation than conflict. Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy reiterated Israel's readiness to engage in peace negotiations without preconditions, despite recent escalations, including Syria's missile testing reports. The call for negotiations comes amid heightened tension since Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's pledge to retain the Golan Heights, with previous peace talks having stalled since February 1991.

Headline: Polish Diplomat Refutes Claims of Nurses Stranded in Libya. Summary: On August 22, 1996, a Polish diplomat denied reports that Libya was refusing exit visas to 100 Polish nurses. Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, the charge d'affaires at the Polish embassy in Tripoli, stated there were no reports of nurses being stranded or held against their will. Poland's labour ministry plans to investigate complaints about work conditions and unpaid salaries for the estimated 800 Polish nurses in Libya.

Headline: Iranian Opposition Leaders Forge Alliance with Kurdish Rebels in Baghdad. Summary: On August 22, 1996, in Baghdad, Mujahideen Khalq leader Massoud Rajavi met with Hassan Rastegar, Secretary-General of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI), to express support for Iranian Kurdish rebels following an attack by Iranian troops in Iraq. This meeting signifies a heightened collaboration between Iranian opposition movements and Kurdish factions, amidst ongoing Iranian military actions targeting KDPI positions. The meeting took place against a backdrop of escalating violence and territorial control struggles in northern Iraq, where Iranian forces have been shelling Kurdish positions, resulting in casualties among Iraqi Kurds.
